Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral Dissertation Research: Who Wants to be an Engineer? Early Adolescence and Girls? Declining Interest in STEM

Although science, technology, engineering, and mathematics [STEM] careers are among the highest paying and most in-demand jobs in the United States, men outnumber women in STEM by nearly four to one. Black and Latina women comprise a mere 4% of the STEM workforce. In middle school, girls begin losing interest and confidence in STEM, and only 13% of high school girls report math as a favorite subject. Existing research identifies gender stereotypes, or beliefs that boys are "naturally" better at STEM, as an overarching reason girls lose interest in STEM subjects and activities. However, there are currently three limitations within existing research: 1) Few studies have examined how girls' daily experiences in school shape their career aspirations; 2) Nearly all girls lose interest in STEM by the end of middle school, but existing research tends to study gender inequality in STEM during high school and beyond; 3) Few studies have identified why and how girls from marginalized backgrounds lose interest in STEM. When taken together, identifying the processes that contribute to girls? declining interest in STEM during early adolescence remains imperative to developing early interventions to increase the representation of girls and women in the STEM workforce.

Drawing upon 2.5 years of longitudinal participant observation and 170 interviews with students, teachers, and staff at a racially diverse public middle school in California, this project traces students' career aspirations as they transition across sixth through eighth grades. Previous research not only risks constructing children as passive recipients of stereotypes pertaining to gender and STEM, but also risks isolating gender from other systems of inequality. Moving beyond these limitations, this project highlights the active role students' interactions play in perpetuating inequality in STEM at the beginning of the occupational pipeline. In addition to contributing to gender, childhood, education, and work scholarship, this project has the potential to create enriched STEM learning environments and increase the representation of women?especially women from marginalized backgrounds?in STEM, thus helping contribute to a diverse and competitive STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

This proposal sought funds for a longitudinal ethnographic and interview study to determine how daily interactions in school shape early adolescent girls’ interest and performance in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics [STEM]. NSF funds were used to offset costs associated with the final year of data collection and analysis, which consisted of one year of participant observation research and 75 interviews conducted with students, teachers, and staff.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Although STEM careers are among the highest paying and most in-demand jobs in the United States, men outnumber women in STEM by nearly four to one, and Black and Latina women comprise a mere 4% of the STEM workforce. In middle school, girls begin losing interest and confidence in STEM, and only 13% of high school girls report math as a favorite subject. Existing research identifies gender stereotypes—or beliefs that boys are “naturally” better at STEM—as an overarching reason girls lose interest in STEM subjects and careers. However, there are three limitations within existing research: 1) Stereotypes pertaining to gender and STEM are created and negotiated during everyday interactions, but few studies have used qualitative methods to examine how daily interactions in school shape girls’ career aspirations; 2) Nearly all girls have lost interest in STEM by the end of middle school, but existing research tends to examine barriers girls face in STEM during high school and beyond; 3) Few studies have taken an intersectional approach to identify why and how girls from marginalized backgrounds lose interest in STEM. When taken together, identifying the interactional processes that contribute to girls’ declining interest in STEM during early adolescence remains imperative to developing early interventions to reduce barriers girls—especially girls from marginalized background—face in STEM.

 

This qualitative longitudinal project traces students’ career aspirations as they transition from childhood to early adolescence, arguing that interactional “push and pull” factors decrease girls’ interest in STEM. Students’ interactions in middle school—such as the way boys hijack classroom conversations in STEM and gendered and racialized divisions within students’ friendship groups—pull boys into STEM and push girls out. Previous research not only risks constructing children as passive recipients of stereotypes pertaining to gender and STEM, but also risks isolating gender from other systems of inequality. Moving beyond these limitations, this project highlights the active role students play in perpetuating inequality in STEM at the beginning of the occupational pipeline and offers early interventions to help increase girls’ interest in STEM.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project is the first to connect girls’ declining interest in STEM to interactional inequality naturalized during early adolescence. Once finished, findings will be widely disseminated to scholarly and public audiences via peer-reviewed journal articles, a book-length manuscript, and op-ed pieces. Furthermore, a key component of this study involved sharing results with teachers, staff, students, and parents at the school where research is being conducted. By widely sharing results with scholars, practitioners, policymakers, students, and the broader public, project findings may inform early interventions to reduce interactional inequality within STEM. Furthermore, with NSF funding, this project hired and trained a research assistants to assist with data analysis, and hiring preference was given to women from groups underrepresented in STEM. Consequently, in addition to making a pivotal contribution to gender, childhood, education, and work research, this project has the potential to create enriched STEM learning environments and increase the representation of women—especially women from marginalized backgrounds—in STEM, thus helping contribute to a diverse and competitive STEM workforce.
